webTitle: Click and collect shoppers predicted to pick up £6.5bn of goods by 2019

fields.standfirst: More than two-thirds of UK shoppers have used method at least once, with fashion items proving most popular
fields.body:
Soaring demand for click and collect services mean shoppers will pick up £6.5bn of goods from lockers, drive-thrus and store pick-up points by 2019 – and 82% increase in current levels – according to a new report.

"The importance of click and collect should not be underestimated. It has become firmly established," said Matthew Rubin of a report into the market for research firm Verdict.

More than two-thirds of UK shoppers have now used click and collect at least once, up from 51% in 2012, with fashion the most likely products to be bought via this method.

The service is helping drive online sales in the UK, where a higher proportion of goods are now bought via the internet than any other major market. Out of every £7 spent, £1 is now spent online – compared to £1 in £11 in the US. UK shoppers spend an average £662 each on online shopping, according to research by OC&C Strategy Consultants for trade journal Retail Week.

Clothing and footwear account for more than half the value of goods ordered using click and collect services, according to Verdict. The researchers predict a 246% in click and collect grocery sales, from a low base. All the major supermarkets are now competing to come up with ideas to attract shoppers who want to buy food online but don't want to wait home for the delivery. Tesco, Asda, Waitrose and Sainsbury's are working with Transport for London to put refrigerated lockers in London Underground car parks while Waitrose is trialling a similar service at Gatwick airport and several supermarkets now offer a drive-thru pick-up service outside their stores.

In contrast, the electrical market is only set to experience a 42% rise in sales over the next five years. That's because it was one of the first sectors to introduce the idea of click and collect with the market expected to be worth £1.6bn by 2019.

webTitle: Phones 4u closure leaves cashback customers sweating over payments

fields.bodyText: Thousands of Phones 4u customers who signed cashback contracts or took out the firm's handset insurance were still waiting to hear on Tuesday whether these deals will be honoured. The retailer shut its 550 stores on Monday, hours before it was put into administration, leaving nearly 5,600 jobs under threat, as a row raged over who was to blame for the chain's demise. Evidence has emerged that in the runup to the retailer's collapse, a significant number of people took out mobile phone cashback deals where they would receive the money either in a single payment or instalments. As recently as last Saturday, Phones 4u was offering a £50 payment on a future date to tempt customers on O2 or Three contracts to switch to Vodafone or EE. Others are apparently owed larger sums. One customer contacted the Guardian to say they had signed up for a contract in which they were due to be sent a cheque for £40 every three months, and were still owed £160. Customers have been advised that any mobile contracts bought through Phones 4u in the past would remain unaffected and carry on as normal, because the contracts were with the major network operators. However, the cashback element was separate from these contracts and paid by Phones 4u. Before it was taken offline, the Phones 4u website carried small print stating that its redemption promotion "is a Phones 4u offer and is separate from the contract agreed between you and your chosen network airtime provider". Technically, these customers could end up becoming creditors of Phones 4u, and if that happens, it is far from clear how much, if any, of their money they would receive. Meanwhile, there was continuing uncertainty for thousands of customers paying for mobile phone insurance from Phones 4u and wondering whether their cover is now worthless. With many of the policies, customers have to take their handset into a Phones 4u shop to make a claim – and at the moment they are all shut, with no word yet on when, or if, they will reopen. The policies are administered by Policy Administration Services, a Phones 4u group company, which was expected to be put into administration on Tuesday. Customers who called the Policy Administration Services helpline to make a claim were met with a message stating: "We are still unable to process your claim while we wait for instruction from the administrator, and we would kindly ask you to call us back at a later date." One member of staff at Policy Administration Services told the Guardian: "It's very touch and go at the moment. We still have no idea [what is happening] – it's all up in the air."

webTitle: Inflation drops to 1.5% after fall in UK food and petrol prices

fields.bodyText: Fierce price wars between supermarkets helped push inflation further down last month but the drop is expected to bring only limited relief to households as wages continue to stall. Official figures showed a fall in food and petrol prices helped inflation drop to 1.5% in August from 1.6% in July, as measured by the consumer price index (CPI). But separate labour market figures released on Wednesday are expected to show average earnings in the three months from May to July were up by just 0.5% on a year ago, only a third of the pace of price inflation. The mismatch between pay and prices was evidence of the "cost of living crisis", the Labour party said. "While this fall in the rate of inflation is welcome, the squeeze on working people continues," said the shadow Treasury minister Catherine McKinnell. The figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) also showed the core measure of inflation, which excludes the more volatile items like food and energy, picked up to 1.9% from 1.8%. The wider retail prices index measure, used to set many pay deals, was down to 2.4% on the year, compared with 2.5% in July. Economists said the numbers suggested price pressures in the economy were benign, with CPI below the Bank of England's 2% target, and would mean the Bank would be in no hurry to raise interest rates. Its monetary policy committee (MPC) has held borrowing costs at a record low of 0.5% for more than five years. But a mixed picture of solid economic growth, falling inflation and uncertainty over the outcome of Thursday's Scotland referendum have made the timing of the first rate rise particularly hard to call. "Inflation is still on a downward trend despite the economic recovery's strength," said Samuel Tombs, senior UK economist at Capital Economics. "Although the low inflation outlook is unlikely to prevent the MPC from raising interest rates entirely over the next couple of years, it should limit the speed at which they rise." The ONS said falling prices of food and non-alcoholic drinks were behind much of the slowdown in the main CPI measure of inflation. That echoed business reports indicating food prices have been falling as supermarkets use discounts to lure back customers from value stores Aldi and Lidl. With oil prices around two-year lows, cheaper fuel also helped bring down inflation last month. Petrol fell by 1.8p a litre between July and August, compared with a rise of 2p a litre last year, the ONS said. Offsetting some of those downward pressures were the prices of clothing, transport services and alcohol. The Treasury welcomed the latest figures. "The government's long-term economic plan is working, with inflation falling by more than two-thirds since its peak in September 2011," said a spokesman. Ministers are likely to get another boost from Wednesday's labour market figures, which are forecast to show the number of people claiming jobseeker's allowance falling below a million for the first time in six years. But the pay figures are likely to remain weak, with annual growth in average earnings recovering only slightly from a surprise drop in last month's data. Last week the Bank of England's governor, Mark Carney, predicted interest rates would probably start to rise before real wage growth returned some time next summer. But economists said the squeeze on households would play some role in the outlook for borrowing costs. Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "We suspect that low inflation, current very weak earnings growth and the increased downside risks to economic activity coming from heightened geopolitical tensions and stuttering eurozone economic activity will cause the Bank of England to hold off from acting until February at the earliest, even though current robust economic activity and markedly falling unemployment provides support to the case for a near-term interest rate hike. The British Chambers of Commerce said the inflation figures reinforced the case against an early rate rise. Chief economist David Kern said: "The main priority for the MPC must be to nurture business confidence by offering the stability of working in a low interest rate environment

webTitle: Barclays, HSBC and RBS among 13 banks facing fraud claims in US

fields.standfirst: Virginia prosecutors seek $1.15bn in damages for allegedly mis-selling risky home loans as AAA-rated mortgage bonds
fields.body:
Barclays, HSBC and bailed-out Royal Bank of Scotland are among 13 banks facing fraud allegations and a claim for $1.15bn (£700m) in damages in the US state of Virginia over the sale of mortgage bonds during the financial crisis.

The Virginia attorney general, Mark Herring, made the accusations, which relate to the sale of bonds to the state's retirement fund from 2004 to 2010.

He alleged the 13 banks packaged up risky home loans into the bonds or securities, which in turn were sold to the Virginia Retirement System as, largely, top-notch AAA-rated bonds. The retirement fund has 600,000 members including teachers, employees from the city and county governments, state troopers, and court employees.

"The message today is clear. It doesn't matter if you're a small-time con artist or a multibillion-dollar Wall Street bank. If you try to rip off or defraud Virginia consumers or Virginia taxpayers, you will be caught and you will be held responsible," said Herring, who is bringing the claim after evidence collated by a whistleblowing analytical firm, IntegraREC.

The case filed in the Richmond circuit court shows the actions of banks in the runup to the financial crisis continue to come under scrutiny by the authorities, potentially undermining attempts by banks to improve reputations that have been knocked by repeated allegations about their behaviour.

Last week HSBC became the latest bank to settle allegations that it made false representations in selling mortgage bonds to the giant US mortgage companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. HSBC paid $550m to the US's Federal Housing Finance Agency, which has filed 18 lawsuits.

Virginia alleges the banks fraudulently misrepresented the quality of the mortgages they packaged up and sold to investors such as the Virginia Retirement System. According to the allegations, 40% of the mortgages sold on to the retirement fund had a higher risk of default than was disclosed at the time they were bought, leading to $383m of losses.

The law allows claims for treble the estimated losses and the 317-page lawsuit also names arms of Citigroup, Countrywide, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, UBS and Washington Mutual.

"Every Virginian was harmed by the financial crisis. Homes were lost, retirement accounts were devastated, small businesses saw their credit dry up almost overnight, and state and federal budget cuts hurt vulnerable Virginians," said Herring.

The lawsuit sets out three ways in which the banks mispresented the quality of the mortgages being sold: the value of the loan compared with the value of the home, the owner occupancy rate and percentage of homes with a second mortgage.

webTitle: Harriet Green interview: 'Thomas Cook was not well'

fields.bodyText: Blame the Russians. Shares in Thomas Cook fell 7% on Tuesday after the travel firm announced sluggish bookings in Germany, its biggest market, where consumer confidence is dwindling as the crisis in Ukraine threatens exports. The company's valuation, down 33% from its springtime high, suggests dampened City expectations in the second year of Thomas Cook's recovery from the brink of bankruptcy. Not that Harriet Green, the chief executive credited with turning round the 173-year-old company, looks worried. She says: "When you've been a serial disappointer like Thomas Cook there are always going to be questions. The only way you turn the doubters into believers and owners of our corporation is continuing to deliver the transformation. There will always be short-term trading and issues, but I think we're incredibly on track." A reality check may help, she hints, after a first year in charge in which the share price has multiplied 10-fold from a low of 14p – the point at which Green picked up 6.2m shares. The trouble is with successful transformation, she says, is that people think it's all done. It isn't. "If you think of this in terms of a remission, you don't want people getting complacent." Green is sitting in head office, her leopard-skin coat on the rack, and a portrait of the firm's Victorian founder behind her. The Veuve Clicquot award for businesswoman of the year sits in a display case opposite, although Green points instead to her RideLondon badge – she says the 100-mile cycling event was the hardest thing she's ever done – and a print, given to her by staff, of one of her favourite quotes: Maya Angelou's observation that people never forget how you made them feel. By and large, it seems, Thomas Cook feels better. Green, fond of a medical metaphor, is clear: "Thomas Cook was not well. The company was very shocked, beleaguered and very confused." There was an unpleasant bout of surgery for staff, with 2,500 jobs cut from a firm where most employees had been happy to stay put despite its troubles: "It was quite alarming in that there was virtually no attrition." Only about a third of senior management were retained. A third were promoted and a third hired from outside. Of the new recruits, she says: "We've had virtually zero organ rejection." Costcutting was less important than a product overhaul, she says, and a change of culture. "The company wasn't working together. It wasn't acting with scale to get benefit. There was virtually no web strategy. We had to leapfrog: mostly focused on tablet and mobile." Bookings from smartphones have more than trebled since the website was relaunched in May, but she says they are still below target. Green, a rare female CEO of a substantial quoted company, speaks passionately for diversity. "When I came to Thomas Cook my direct reports were all male and British or German. Now I have six different ethnicities and nationalities." That's not driven by her own gender, she says, but by the customer base, with 70% of holidays booked by women. But she says 13- and 14-year-old girls don't have good enough role models, something she would like to change "if I was PM or ran the BBC, though all of these jobs are filled by perfectly effective people: getting young women to think about what it means to be a journalist, a doctor, a business person … I think Theresa May is amazing. How do you get to be Theresa May, 13-year-olds?" Boards and recruiters don't do enough but, she says, echoing Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg, women must take responsibility too. "Some of it is us. We have to be bolder and more assertive and make choices about what we really want to do." And stronger too, it seems. Green survives on three hours' sleep and works out for an hour a day, mainly rowing and kettlebells - a Russian-inspired workout. "Strong is the new thin, so I'm trying to be stronger and not thinner." Another favourite quote of Green's is Nelson Mandela's dictum to be the change you want to see in the world [see footnote]. But, she notes: "People like the notion of very challenging women but not always the reality." Earlier this year she caused some dismay by saying a year's maternity leave was too much, but she insists the headlines did not tell the full story: she is "a strong proponent … of making sure women if they wish to can return", and has instigated buddying schemes at her companies to keep new mothers in the loop. Her big idea is a lifetime allowance of leave for parents. "You never know when children need your time and support, it isn't always when they're little." Diversity helps firms, she says: "Groupthink is dangerous. I try to add a point of view that is coloured by a grammar school education, reading medieval history – but sitting on heavy-hitting boards; having lived and worked in four continents." One of those boards is BAE Systems, the defence manufacturer, to which Green brings her interest in Middle East peace charities. "I don't think those are mutually exclusive. The PeaceWorks Foundation and One Voice aim to embrace the views of the moderates … Hopefully that's doing some good. If it doesn't, and you're seeing the line play out perfectly, then trying to maintain stability in the region through the force of other things, as opposed to negotiations … I think you have to look at intractable problems from both ends." Having joined two years ago from electronics firm Premier Farnell as an outsider, Green is optimistic about the travel sector, "a growth industry – we have people inquiring about space vacations, travel to Iran …", although she says Africa is facing difficulties: "The Ebola virus has meant a large number of people have decided that isn't on their list." Green joined industry from her history studies, having earlier considered journalism and, having been brought up with amateur dramatics, she also toyed with applying to Rada. But performing, she says, is a key part of her job: "There are many times as a CEO when you have to perform. When we were doing the huge £1.6bn capital raise, we had lots of bank meetings, quite dry … You can't think: 'Shit, this is the fifth I've done.' Every meeting has to be as good as you can possibly be." • This footnote was appended on 19 September 2014: the dictum that Harriet Green attributed to Nelson Mandela is more often ascribed to Gandhi, although it is unclear whether he said it; it is possibly a paraphrase of something he wrote. A book published in 1989 attributed the words "We must be the change we wish to see in the world" to Gandhi, and in a 2001 interview Arun Gandhi said his grandfather used to say "Be the change you wish to see".

The PeaceWorks Foundation and One Voice aim to embrace the views of the moderates … Hopefully that's doing some good. If it doesn't, and you're seeing the line play out perfectly, then trying to maintain stability in the region through the force of other things, as opposed to negotiations … I think you have to look at intractable problems from both ends."

Having joined two years ago from electronics firm Premier Farnell as an outsider, Green is optimistic about the travel sector, "a growth industry – we have people inquiring about space vacations, travel to Iran …", although she says Africa is facing difficulties: "The Ebola virus has meant a large number of people have decided that isn't on their list."

Green joined industry from her history studies, having earlier considered journalism and, having been brought up with amateur dramatics, she also toyed with applying to Rada. But performing, she says, is a key part of her job: "There are many times as a CEO when you have to perform. When we were doing the huge £1.6bn capital raise, we had lots of bank meetings, quite dry … You can't think: 'Shit, this is the fifth I've done.' Every meeting has to be as good as you can possibly be."

• This footnote was appended on 19 September 2014: the dictum that Harriet Green attributed to Nelson Mandela is more often ascribed to Gandhi, although it is unclear whether he said it; it is possibly a paraphrase of something he wrote. A book published in 1989 attributed the words "We must be the change we wish to see in the world" to Gandhi, and in a 2001 interview Arun Gandhi said his grandfather used to say "Be the change you wish to see".

webTitle: Online fashion firms Asos, Boohoo.com and N Brown see shares slide

fields.standfirst: Shares in Asos drop nearly 9% to £22.07 and more than £190m is wiped off company's value after profits warning issued
fields.body:
More than £190m was wiped off the value of online fashion group Asos on Tuesday after the retailer issued its third profits warning in six months as it struggles to conquer new territories.

N Brown and Boohoo.com also saw their shares slide after the former tinkered with its marketing plans and investors worried that the online fashion chains might struggle to find profitable growth, particularly in international markets.

Shares in the one-time stockmarket favourite Asos sank nearly 9% to £22.07, less than a third of their value in February, as it admitted it would have to invest more in technology and in cutting prices in overseas markets because the high value of the pound was making its clothing look expensive in key markets including the US and Russia.

Total sales rose by 15% to £240m over the summer compared with the same period last year, boosted by a healthy 33% increase in the UK which still accounts for 41% of Asos's business. But sales in overseas market rose just 6% as growth in the US completely stalled and sales went into reverse in the rest of the world outside Europe.

The group warned that profits for its 2015 financial year were likely to be the same as this year at about £45m because of the need to invest in lowering prices overseas and the technology necessary to enable it to alter prices by country. Analysts polled by Bloomberg had been expecting a recovery to £63m next year.

Asos said that a fire at its main warehouse in June had reduced sales by between £20m and £30m but the impact of that problem would be covered by insurance.

Asos' chief executive, Nick Robertson, said the business remained "focused on the long term opportunity," adding that the company had attracted a quarter more active customers.

But analysts said the figures were disappointing and some suggested Asos was facing increasing competition from rivals such as Zalando, the German online fashion store in which Asos shareholder Anders Holch Povlsen also owns a large stake, as well as high street retailers including Topshop and Zara. Robertson said there hadn't been major changes among the competition, but Zalando had had "the biggest impact".

"After this update, in particular the revision to [next year's] forecasts, there will inevitably be questions over the robustness of the company's model, particularly its development strategy overseas," said retail analyst Freddie George of Cantor Fitzgerald in a note.

Fellow online fashion store N Brown also saw its shares slide 5% to 385p as it admitted that changes in the timing of marketing and a cutback on sales of less profitable, but high value, electrical products, had hit sales. Underlying sales at the group, which owns the Figleaves, Simply Be and JD Williams brands, slumped by 4.6% in the three months to the end August, as sales of home and gift items dived 9% and spending on marketing using traditional catalogues was slashed by nearly a quarter. In the previous quarter the group had recorded 2.5% growth.

Its chief executive, Angela Spindler, admitted "August was below where we wanted to be," but said the company would still meet its profit target. "We are confident we are doing the right thing to modernise the business and create a platform for growth. We don't have underlying performance issues," she insisted.

But analysts worried that warm weather in September would continue to depress sales despite the screening of the first TV campaign for JD Williams' led by new brand ambassador Lorraine Kelly this month.

An analyst at Investec Securities, Kate Calvert, said the decline in sales in the last three months had been worse than expected. She said: "Investors are unlikely to give this 'jam tomorrow' story the benefit of the doubt."

webTitle: Labour: cost of living squeeze continues despite lower inflation - business live

fields.bodyText: Nervousness was evident among investors once more, writes Nick Fletcher, ahead of this week’s Scottish referendum and the latest decisions from the US Federal Reserve on Wednesday. There were other reasons to be cautious, with worries about the effect of sanctions on Russia over its actions in Ukraine (one of the reasons for a dip in German confidence) and a dip in inward investment in China raising concerns about its growth outlook. But news that the People’s Bank of China was increasing liquidity to its leading banks helped limit some of the damage. So the final scores showed: The FTSE 100 finished down 11.97 points at 6792.24 Germany’s Dax dipped 0.28% to 9632.93 France’s Cac closed 0.44% lower at 4409.15 Italy’s FTSE MIB slipped 0.3% to 20,788.50 Spain’s Ibex ended 0.39% down at 10,789.7 But reports that the Fed may not be as hawkish in its comments tomorrow as some feared have helped push the Dow Jones Industrial Average 90 points or 0.53% higher. On that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments and we’ll be back tomorrow. More on the forthcoming polls on the Scottish referendum from analyst Mike Smithson: Looking for some afternoon reading? Here’s Larry Elliott, reminding us that September has often been a bad month for sterling: April is the cruellest month, TS Eliot once wrote.Not for the pound, it isn’t. Without question the month that holds the maximum danger for sterling is September. What’s more, this week – the week in which Scotland decides whether it wants to become an independent country – tends to be the scariest week of the scariest month. Consider the evidence. There were five big sterling crises in the 20th century, and four of them came to the boil in September. In the circumstances, it’s not hard to see why foreign exchange dealers will be at their desks early on Friday morning to await news from Edinburgh about the referendum vote. The story starts in 1931, two years after the Wall Street Crash and six years after Sir Winston Churchill had, with some misgivings, put Britain back on the Gold Standard at its pre first world war rate. This involved a revaluation of the pound, a move that made UK exports more expensive. Industry’s pain intensified when global trade started to contract in the early years of the Great Depression. The Labour government of James Ramsay Macdonald found that it could only balance the budget by imposing spending cuts that led to a split in the party and the formation of a coalition. International investors were spooked by a mutiny of sailors at Invergordon and capital flight was not staunched by an austerity budget. Sterling left the Gold Standard forever on 21 September 1931. For more drama, click here: The pound and September: a torrid month for Britain’s currency Time to recap (do scroll back through the blog for more details, charts and reaction) Inflation in the UK has fallen back to its joint-lowest level in five year. Falling fuel and food bills helped to lower the Consumer Prices index to just 1.5% in August. The fall was welcomed by government ministers including chancellor George Osborne. But the Labour party, and the TUC union, both warned that the cost of living squeeze continues to hurt households. TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady says: With inflation well under control there is no case for raising interest rates any time soon. It would dump higher mortgage costs on households still feeling a squeeze on their living standards and risk choking off economic recovery. “As the Governor of the Bank of England said last week, British workers have faced pay cuts deeper than at any time since the 1920s. The priority now has to be wage rises to ensure a sustained economic recovery and a return to growing living standards.” The drop takes the pressure off the Bank of England to raise interest rates, predicts Samuel Tombs of Capital Economics: “Inflation is still on a downward trend despite the economic recovery’s strength. Although the low inflation outlook is unlikely to prevent the MPC from raising interest rates entirely over the next couple of years, it should limit the speed at which they rise.” House prices have continued to climb, pushing average Scottish prices to record highs. The average UK home value has risen by 11.9% in the last year. And houses in London jumped by 19%, meaning the average house in the capital now costs £514,000. Elsewhere.... There’s no sign of rampant inflation in the US, with producer prices flat in August. The OECD has proposed a clampdown on multinationals avoiding paying their fair share of tax. The Ukraine crisis has pushed German investor confidence down to a two-year low. And it’s helped to sent the Russian ruble down to its lowest ever point against the US dollar And on Scotland.... An investor survey has found that Thursday’s Scottish independence vote has hit appetite for investing in the UK Betfair is paying out to punters who bet that Scotland will reject independence.... (some customers, anyway) ...while the boss of Thomas Cook has predicted that Scots will still want a break from “one of the worst climates in the world” if they vote yes. And with more polls due tonight, the markets remain tense..... Something to ponder.... Update: Can there be a surprise outcome when the polls are neck-and-neck, one reader asks? Well, Betfair has just paid out on No bets, so they’d look pretty daft if the Yes side win. Good point, though.... The boss of Thomas Cook, Harriet Green, has argued that Scottish independence won’t hit demand for holidays as Scots will want to visit somewhere with better weather. The Daily Telegraph’s Denise Roland reports that Green said: “My personal view is we’re stronger together [but] Scots have shown enormous resilience. It has one of the worst climates in the world and vacation is extremely important.” She was speaking after Thomas Cook reported a slowdown in demand in Germany: Thomas Cook experiences slowdown in German holiday bookings The Scottish referendum has encouraged some international investors to pull money out of the UK, according to a regular survey from Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Here’s the section on “Scottish fears:, via the WSJ: “As opinion polls indicated the referendum for Scottish independence was too close to call, negativity towards U.K. stocks deepened. The U.K. has entrenched its status as the world’s least popular region among asset allocators this month. A net 16% of the panel is underweight U.K. equities.” The outlook is also dim, according to BoA. The U.K. is the region that 14% of global investors want to underweight in the coming year. One in five investors said the region has the least favorable profit outlook, up from a net 12% in August. Investors, often a jittery bunch,, are also worried about geopolitical tensions, the weak eurozone economy, and the consequences if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates next year. More here. Here’s something for US Federal Reserve policymakers to ponder as they meet today; the prices charged “at the factory gate” by American companies were unchanged in August. The 0.0% change in the Producer Prices index, released a few minute ago, surprised economists who expected a 0.1% rise. The Labor Department reports that falling gasoline and food costs cancelled out higher rising service sector prices, and kept the overall PPI unchanged. On an annual basis, though, producer prices increased by 1.8% after rising 1.7% in July. The Fed’s two-day monetary policy meeting ends tomorrow. Multinational companies who play the system to slash their tax bills could face a clampdown, if new rules just announced by the OECD are imposed by G20 counties this week. My colleague Simon Bowers reports: Bold updates to international tax rules designed to force some of the world’s biggest multinationals – including Google, Apple, Amazon,Vodafone and GlaxoSmithKline – to contribute their fair share towards government budgets are to be agreed by G20 countries this weekend. A package of draft rules and progress reports, published on Tuesday by tax experts from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), marks the halfway milestone in a two-year reform project which was set in train by world leaders in Moscow last summer. Many of the world’s largest and best known corporations now face being forced to rapidly dismantle their elaborate cross-border corporate structures as governments move in unison in an attempt to corral them back within a joined-up and modernised network of international tax treaties. Full story: International tax rule updates to be agreed by G20 countries And here’s Phillip Inman on today’s record-breaking housing data: UK house prices hit new record as London average breaks £500,000 The pound has recovered some of this morning’s losses in the last few minutes, and is now trading just over $1.62 (having hit $1.616 this morning). It jumped after online bookmakers Betfair announced it is paying out to anyone who wagered that the No side would win Thursday’s Scottish referendum. A reminder for eurozone crisis watchers, French PM Manuel Valls faces a confidence vote this afternoon. The result could determine how much authority Valls has to implement economic reforms to stimulate growth in the French economy. From Paris, Kim Willsher reports: The French prime minister, Manuel Valls, will put his political career on the line on Tuesday afternoon by seeking a crucial vote of confidence from parliament in his programme to tackle the country’s economic woes. Valls, who formed a new government less than four weeks ago, needs to quell dissent that has brought bitter divisions in the ruling Socialist party (PS) and overcome president François Hollande’s record unpopularity, to obtain a clear mandate from the lower house, the Assemblée Nationale. He is expected to win the vote, but will need a very clear majority to silence the critics and give him enough support to push through proposed reforms. A narrow victory could leave parliament paralysed just weeks before the government seeks approval of its 2015 budget bill..... Full story here. Another landmark in the UK housing market.... the average London house price now costs more than half a million pounds. In this morning’s survey, the Office for National Statistics reports that houses in the capital are now 39.7% higher than the pre-financial crisis peak in January 2008. London, unsurprisingly, is the English region with the highest average house price at £514,000 and the North East had the lowest average house price at £156,000. London, the South East and the East all had prices higher than the UK average price of £272,000, according to the ONS. The FT’s John Aglionby says: The figure will damp claims that the market is cooling and maintain pressure on the government and the Bank of England to act to contain house price inflation. Here’s my colleague Katie Allen on today’s inflation report: Inflation drops to 1.5% after fall in food and petrol prices A drop in food and petrol prices helped inflation edge lower last month, pushing it down to 1.5% from 1.6% in July, as measured by the consumer price index. Figures from the Office for National Statistics showed the wider retail prices index (RPI) measure used to set many pay deals was down to 2.4% on the year, compared with 2.5% in July. Both rates were as forecast by economists and they said the relatively benign price pressure in the economy would mean the Bank of England is in no hurry to raise interest rates. Its monetary policy committee (MPC) has held borrowing costs at a record low of 0.5% for more than five years. “Inflation is still on a downward trend despite the economic recovery’s strength,” said Samuel Tombs, senior UK economist at Capital Economics. “Although the low inflation outlook is unlikely to prevent the MPC from raising interest rates entirely over the next couple of years, it should limit the speed at which they rise.”... Full story here. Calum Bennie, savings expert at building society Scottish Friendly, warns against assuming that interest rates will remain at their record lows indefinitely: “While lower inflation may reduce the likelihood of interest rates going up in short term, it is unrealistic to think that they will not rise in the midterm. It is important that people retain a healthy dose of caution; going on a spending blitz before the festive season is not the answer. High street retailers might disagree..... Just noticed that George Osborne tweeted about the dip in inflation: The TUC has echoed Labour’s concerns over the weak UK wage growth. General Secretary Frances O’Grady also argues that the Bank of England should hold of raising interest rates until earnings pick up: “With inflation well under control there is no case for raising interest rates any time soon. It would dump higher mortgage costs on households still feeling a squeeze on their living standards and risk choking off economic recovery. “As the Governor of the Bank of England said last week, British workers have faced pay cuts deeper than at any time since the 1920s. The priority now has to be wage rises to ensure a sustained economic recovery and a return to growing living standards.” Tomorrow, the BoE will publish the minutes of this month’s monetary policy committee meeting, which will show how many MPC members voted to raise raises. In August, two policymakers wanted to hike borrowing costs. Even though the inflation rate is back at a five year low, prices in the shops are rising faster than average pay rises. Catherine McKinnell MP, Labour’s Shadow Treasury Minister, says that Britons still face significant cost of living pressure: “While this fall in the rate of inflation is welcome, the squeeze on working people continues. “The most recent figures show pay rising by a record low of just 0.6 per cent - less than half the rate of inflation. Wages after inflation have now fallen by over £1,600 a year under this Government. “Labour’s economic plan will tackle the cost-of-living crisis, make Britain better off and earn our way to higher living standards for all, not just a few.” This chart from last month shows how UK pay growth have lagged inflation since around 2010, meaning real wages have shrunk: Arguably, workers’ willingness to accept falling real wages helped to prevent unemployment rising higher during the downturn. Alasdair Cavalla, economist at the Centre for Economics and Business Research, says that this weak wage growth has also helped peg inflation. Cavalla says: Two main factors have kept the UK inflation rate below the Bank of England’s central target of 2.0% over the past eight months. Weak wage growth for consumers has helped prevent prices from taking off with the recovery. In this sense, the low inflation rate is something of a relief as it has prevented living standards from falling too far over the year so far. Geopolitics is another factor, he adds: On the global level, Eurozone demand has taken a knock from the unexpected shock of the Ukraine crisis, reducing pressure on global prices such as commodities and energy. This happened against the backdrop of weakening Chinese growth, an expected development but nevertheless one which has had a downward impact on key prices. Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank also points out that core inflation (+1.9%) remains higher than the main CPI index. That showing that some of the easing in price pressures is due to volatile factors like the oil price and global food costs. Wood says: Inflation is below the BoE’s 2% target mainly because of volatile food and energy prices. Core inflation actually rose to 1.9%yoy in August, from 1.8% in July, reflecting the rise in air fares and clothing prices. So the underlying inflationary picture is not as subdued as the headlines suggest. The British Chambers of Commerce has long been arguing against an early rise in interest rates, and today’s fall in inflation has strengthened their case. BCC chief economist David Kern says: “These figures highlight that inflationary pressures in the economy are easing and remain well below the 2% target. The drop in inflation alongside the recent stagnation in wage growth will relieve pressure on the Bank of England. While the UK recovery remains on track, this is clearly not the time to put the recovery at risk with premature interest rate rises. “The main priority for the MPC must be to nurture business confidence by offering the stability of working in a low interest rate environment. To secure a lasting recovery the government should continue to provide further measures in key areas such as improving access to finance for growing firms, and supporting UK exporters.” The consumer prices index is likely to remain below the 2% target until the middle of next year, reckons Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight. He predicts the Bank of England will raise interest rates in February 2015, nearly six years after cutting them to the current record low of 0.5%. But the BoE could resist hiking for even longer, he adds, despite the recent growth in employment: We suspect that low inflation, current very weak earnings growth, and the increased downside risks to economic activity coming from heightened geopolitical tensions and stuttering Eurozone economic activity will cause the Bank of England to hold off from acting until February at the earliest even though current ongoing robust economic activity and markedly falling unemployment provides support to the case for a near-term interest rate hike. I’m going to mop up the best reaction to today’s inflation data.... ....starting with Jeremy Cook, chief economist at World First, who points out that underlying inflation was higher than the headline CPI reading. “Of course, the headline figure does not tell the full story. Core prices surprised higher by 1.9% in August; they were unaffected by the slips in oil prices or the 1.1% decline in food and booze through the past 12 months.” A Treasury spokesperson says: The government’s long term economic plan is working, with inflation falling by more than two-thirds since its peak in September 2011. Danny Alexander, the chief secretary to the Treasury, has welcomed the drop in inflation in August...and used it as a hook to urge Scots to reject the chance of independence. He says: ‘Today’s inflation figures are another step on the long road to our economic recovery after the great crash of 2008. They come just days before the most important vote on these islands in living memory. This recovery is just one of the countless endeavours that we have shared during our hundreds of years of joint history as a United Kingdom. It’s another example that shows that by being together, our family of nations has the combined strength to overcome the challenges that life in an uncertain world inevitably throws up’. Over to Germany briefly, and the Ukraine crisis has hit investor confidence hard. The monthly ZEW index, which tracks morale in Europe’s largest economy, has slumped to just 6.9 this month, down from 8.6 in August. That’s the lowest level since December 2012, and the ninth fall in a row. The gauge of current conditions plunged to 25.4 from 44.3 in August. ZEW, the think tank, blamed the fall on rising uncertainty over Germany’s economic prospects, given the risk of spiralling sanctions against Russia, and the disappointing stare of the eurozone economy. Those house price figures aren’t adjusted for inflation, by the way.... Scottish house prices have hit their highest level ever, rising above the pre-crisis peak of 2008. Today’s housing data (see 9.38am) shows that in the year to July 2014, average house prices increased by 12.0% in England, 7.4% in Wales, 7.6% in Scotland and 4.5% in Northern Ireland. This has pushed house prices in Scotland to new record highs, for the first time since the financial crisis, the Office for National Statistics reports. It says (on page 6 of the report): Scotland average house prices have now passed their pre-financial crisis peak of June 2008, and along with average prices in England are at record levels. Prices in Wales are now 0.8% below their pre-crisis peak. But in Northern Ireland, they are still 46.7% below their record levels (set in 2007). This chart shows more details of how the cost of living in the UK changed in August: The full inflation report is online here (pdf). Here’s the details of why the UK inflation rate fell in August: Falls in the price of motor fuels and food & non-alcoholic drinks produced the main downward effects on the headline rate between July and August. Petrol prices fell by 1.8 pence per litre between the two months this year, compared with a rise of 2.0 pence per litre a year ago. Similarly, diesel prices fell by 2.1 pence this year but rose by 2.0 pence a year ago. Prices of food also fell this year but rose a year ago, particularly in the milk, cheese and eggs category. But the prices of some items picked up pace last month, including alcoholic drinks and women’s clothing. Offsetting these were upward effects from clothing, transport services and alcohol. Clothing prices rose, as usual, between July and August as autumn ranges started to enter the shops following the summer sales season and this year the increases were greater than a year ago. The main effect came from price rises on women’s outerwear. Within transport services, the upward effect came from sea and air transport and within alcohol, it came from spirits and wine. At 1.5%, the consumer prices index is back at its joint lowest level since 2009: But while inflation fell, house prices have surged at their fastest rate in seven years. Average house prices in the UK jumped by 11.7% in the year to July, according to ONS data. That’s the biggest monthly rise since 2007. In London, they are up by 19.1% over the last year. The drop in inflation in August was mainly due to falling fuel, food, non-alcoholic beverage costs, according to the Office for National Statistics. The Retail Prices Index, the inflation measure that also includes housing costs, has also fallen. It dropped to 2.4% in August, from 2.5% in July. Breaking: The UK inflation rate, as measures by the Consumer Prices Index has fallen to 1.5%. That equals May’s five-year low. Details and reaction to follow.... OK, it’s nearly time for the main event of the morning, the UK inflation data for August. A reminder, we’re expecting the consumer prices index to fall to 1.5% in August, from 1.6% last month. That would equal May’s five-year low..... Today is also the 22nd anniversary of Black Wednesday, when Britain was sent packing out of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism after being outgunned by speculator George Soros. At the time, Black Wednesday felt like a major humiliation for the UK. The government clung on, although John Major later admitted he came close to resigning after a dramatic day in which interest rates were (briefly) hiked twice in a bid to support the pound. But more than two decades later, losing the pound’s peg against rival currencies such as the Deutsche Mark looks like a blessing in disguise. Devaluing sterling appears to have been the trigger that ended the early-1990s recession and heralded years of growth. The Russian ruble has tumbled to fresh record lows today, as the selloff that began yesterday intensified. An early burst of selling drove the ruble down 1%, to 38.732 to the US dollar. It has now lost 14% of its value since July, and 18% since the start of this year. Kit Juckes of Société Générale says the ruble’s weakness is “highlighting the return of geopolitical risk”. And there are several reasons for the ruble’s slide. 1) Reuters cites the “hefty” foreign debt repayments which Russian companies face this month, which pushes up demand for US dollars and also leads to more foreign capital leaving Russia. 2) A former Russian finance minister, Alexei Kudrin, predicted this morning that the Russian economy could be plunged into a deep recession of Western governments implement tougher sanctions. 3) Morgan Stanley has warned that Russia’s credit rating could be cut further, if the Ukraine crisis continues. Alexei Mikheev, an analyst at VTB 24 bank’s investment department, summed up the mood thus: “You could characterise the behaviour of the market on the dollar-rouble pair as panicky and irrational.” Thomas Cook’s results have also failed to wow the market. Its shares are down almost 6%, leading the FTSE 250 fallers, even though earnings hit forecasts. The holiday firm did warn that price growth remained weak, which it combated by accelerating its cost-cutting measures. More here. The pound is losing some ground this morning, down half a cent or 0.33% against the US dollar at $1.6175. Against the euro, it’s down 0.3% at €1.2501. Analysts continue to predict that sterling will tumble if the Yes campaign win Thursday’s Scottish referendum vote. Disappointing profits forecasts are never in fashion in the City, as web clothing retailer Asos is learning this morning. Shares in Asos slumped by 15% at the start of trading, after the company downgraded its earning expectations for the 2014-15 financial year. The company dashed hopes of increased profits, saying it needed to make more “significant investments in our international pricing and proposition, as well as in our logistical infrastructure and technology platform”. ASOS also reported that the fire at its Barnsley warehouse in June cost it between £25m and £30m in lost sales. The Press Association reports that a “sharper-than-expected change in inflation” this morning could shake up the market’s expectations of when interest rates rise. IHS Global Insight chief UK economist Howard Archer said price pressure in the UK economy is muted, with Brent crude oil prices trading at two-year lows in September and the pound at a relatively strong level, despite recent volatility due to the Scottish independence referendum. Mr Archer added: “The inflation environment currently looks benign, particularly with supermarkets heavily engaged in a food price war.” Global Insight said it expected CPI to remain at around the current levels and clearly under 2% over the rest of 2014 and through the early months of 2015. But Capital Economics, which predicts CPI to drop to around 1.4% today, said the inflation measure could hit 1% by the end of 2014. It said: “We continue to think that a combination of stable energy bills, lower import prices and weak growth in unit wages will enable CPI inflation to fall to as low as 1% by the end of this year and remain weak in 2015.” The Retail Prices Index, the broader measure of inflation, is expected to also drop from July’s 2.5% to 2.4%, according to a Reuters poll. Even if UK inflation does fall to 1.5%, it will mean prices are rising ahead of wage growth. The latest labour market figures, released last month, showed that average earnings (ex-bonuses) grew by just 0.6% annually in the three months to June. We get fresh data tomorrow. The pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates could ease today, with the release of the latest UK inflation rate, for August, at 9.30am BST. Economists predict that the Consumer Prices Index fell last month, from 1.6% to 1.5%, further from the BoE’s 2% target, partly thanks to lower energy costs. As Jasper Lawler of CMC Markets explains, that would reduce the chances of a hike in borrowing costs: All things equal, a drop in inflation today especially alongside a fall in wages tomorrow would ease pressure on the Bank of England over hiking rates and add more pressure onto an oversold British pound. It will be matter of judging the need for a rate hike as suggested by data against the committee’s hawkishness in tomorrow’s minutes [of this month’s meeting] for the chance of a change in expected timeline for the first rate hike. Mind you, if Scotland votes for independence on Thursday, the resulting turmoil would probably make an early interest rate rise rather unlikely.... Prime Minister Manuel Valls should survive it, despite Francois Hollande’s slumping popularity and concerns over the weak French economy....
